MongoDB Overview

MongoDB is a NoSQL database, meaning it stores data in a non-relational format. Unlike traditional relational databases that use tables and rows, MongoDB stores data in flexible, JSON-like documents (called BSON in MongoDB), which makes it highly scalable and suitable for handling large volumes of unstructured or semi-structured data.

Key Features of MongoDB:

  • Document-Based: Data is stored in flexible documents (BSON) instead of rigid tables.
  • Schema-less: Collections do not require a predefined structure, allowing flexibility in the data schema.
  • Scalability: MongoDB is built for horizontal scaling, making it ideal for applications that need to handle large amounts of data and traffic.
  • Indexing: Supports indexing to improve query performance.
  • Replication & Sharding: MongoDB supports replication (for high availability) and sharding (for horizontal scaling).
  • Aggregation Framework: Allows data transformation and processing similar to SQL's GROUP BY and JOIN operations.
  • High Performance: Optimized for both read and write operations at scale.

Use Cases:

  • Big Data Applications
  • Real-time Analytics
  • Content Management Systems (CMS)
  • Internet of Things (IoT) applications

MongoDB is popular for applications requiring fast development cycles, scalability, and flexible data models.
